contentrichtext.text: The '''Mann–Elkins Act''' was a 1910 [[United States federal law]] that was among the [[Progressivism in the United States|Progressive era]] reforms.<ref>Mann-Elkins Act, [[61st Congress]], 2nd session, ch. 309, {{USStat|36|539}}, enacted June 18, 1910.</ref> The Act extended the authority of the [[Interstate Commerce Commission]] (ICC) to regulate the [[telecommunication]]s industry, and designated [[Telephone company|telephone]], [[Telegraphy|telegraph]] and [[Wireless telegraphy|wireless]] companies as [[common carrier]]s.<ref name="Sharfman">{{cite book |title=Railway Regulation: An Analysis of the Underlying Problems in Railway Economics from the Standpoint of Government Regulation |last=Sharfman |first=Isaiah L. |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1915 |publisher=La Salle Extension University |location=Chicago |isbn= |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=g-pCAAAAIAAJ&dq=Mann-elkins&pg=PA216#v=onepage&q=Mann-elkins&f=false |accessdate=}}</ref>{{rp|216}} During William H. Taft's administration, the federal government moved to strengthen its regulatory control over the railroad industry by the passage of the Mann–Elkins Act. Supported by [[President]] [[William Howard Taft]], the law also expanded on the powers granted to the ICC in the 1906 [[Hepburn Act]]. The ICC was authorized to investigate proposed railroad rate increases and suspend them if warranted. The "long-and-short haul" clause of the original [[Interstate Commerce Act]] (1887) was strengthened to prohibit railroads from charging passengers more for a short distance trip, compared to a longer distance ride, over the same route, unless specifically approved by the ICC.<ref name="Sharfman" />{{rp|217-219}} The Act also created the short-lived [[United States Commerce Court]] for adjudication of railway disputes.<ref name="Sharfman" />{{rp|216}} The Court presided until 1913, when it was abolished by [[United States Congress|Congress]].<ref>Urgent Deficiency Act, [[63rd United States Congress|63rd Congress]], 1st session, ch. 32, {{USStat|38|208}}, October 22, 1913. Effective December 31, 1913.</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Modern American Law |last1=Gilmore |first1=Eugene A. |last2=Wermuth |first2=William C. |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=1917 |publisher=Blackstone Institute |location=Chicago |isbn= |chapter=III. The Various United States Courts and their Jurisdiction: The Commerce Court (Abolished). |pages=278–280 |url=http://books.google.com/books?id=Igs9AAAAIAAJ&lpg=PA278&ots=0xXb7JCTVb&dq=%22commerce%20court%22%20abolished&pg=PA278#v=onepage&q=%22commerce%20court%22%20abolished&f=false |accessdate=}}</ref> ==Legislative history== It was passed by the [[United States Senate]], 50-12. {{Expand section|date=June 2008}} ==See also== * [[Elkins Act]] (1903) * [[History of rail transport in the United States]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mann-Elkins Act}} [[Category:1910 in law]] [[Category:United States federal transportation legislation]] [[Category:United States railroad regulation]] [[Category:1910 in rail transport]] [[Category:1910 in the United States]] [[Category:Progressive Era in the United States]] {{US-fed-statute-stub}}
